## 1.  How “deterrence” is measured

| Concept | Typical operationalisation | What it captures |
|---------|----------------------------|------------------|
| **General deterrence** | Change in homicide‑rate (or other violent‑crime rate) after a jurisdiction adopts, repeals, or changes the frequency of executions. | Effect on the *population at large* – “will I be less likely to kill because I might be executed?” |
| **Specific deterrence** | Recidivism of convicted murderers who receive death vs. life‑without‑parole (LWOP). | Effect on the *individual offender* – “does the sentence stop that person from killing again?” |
| **“Brutalization” effect** | Whether homicide rates *rise* after executions (the opposite of deterrence). | Possible “copy‑cat” or “revenge” dynamics. |

Because the death penalty is rare (often <1 execution per 100 000 people per year) and murders are already low‑frequency events, any statistical signal is small and easily swamped by other factors (economic cycles, policing, gun availability, etc.). This makes causal inference extremely difficult and explains why studies sometimes reach opposite conclusions even when using similar data.
